channel.title: Java's Robot "createScreenCapture", is there anything better?
channel.description:
So far I have only found that I can just use reflection on the RobotPeer class to use a direct method of getting the data ( java.awt.peer.RobotPeer.getRGBPixels(int x, int y, int w, int h, int[] rgb) ). You can download what I use to test the speeds of it. On my computer (1024mb of ram, 32mb graphics card, 1280 X 1024 display, 75 refresh rate, 32 bit color, 2.0ghz processor) I get around 1.5fps at 500-600 milliseconds per frame. I plan on making remote desktop protocol/program. But with these speeds, it will never hapen. I belive that the JNI for this synchronizes the entire screen while it copys it all, causing your screen modifications to stop while it until it finishes. Please post your computer's informations ( ram, graphics card info, display size, refresh rate, color bitdepth (normally 32), and processor info ) and the output of the screen capture program.
[code] device [accelerated-mem:NaN] display [width:1280 height:1024 bit-depth:32 refresh-rate:75] capture [ms:628 avrg-ms:628 fps:1.5923566878980893 avrg-fps:1.5923566878980893] capture [ms:616 avrg-ms:622 fps:1.6233766233766234 avrg-fps:1.607717041800643] capture [ms:700 avrg-ms:661 fps:1.4285714285714286 avrg-fps:1.51285930408472] capture [ms:630 avrg-ms:645 fps:1.5873015873015872 avrg-fps:1.550387596899225] capture [ms:625 avrg-ms:635 fps:1.6 avrg-fps:1.5748031496062993] capture [ms:620 avrg-ms:627 fps:1.6129032258064515 avrg-fps:1.594896331738437] capture [ms:681 avrg-ms:654 fps:1.4684287812041117 avrg-fps:1.529051987767584] capture [ms:630 avrg-ms:642 fps:1.5873015873015872 avrg-fps:1.557632398753894] capture [ms:645 avrg-ms:643 fps:1.550387596899225 avrg-fps:1.5552099533437014] capture [ms:622 avrg-ms:632 fps:1.607717041800643 avrg-fps:1.5822784810126582] capture [ms:631 avrg-ms:631 fps:1.5847860538827259 avrg-fps:1.5847860538827259] capture [ms:626 avrg-ms:628 fps:1.597444089456869 avrg-fps:1.5923566878980893] capture [ms:631 avrg-ms:629 fps:1.5847860538827259 avrg-fps:1.589825119236884] capture [ms:621 avrg-ms:625 fps:1.6103059581320451 avrg-fps:1.6] capture [ms:626 avrg-ms:625 fps:1.597444089456869 avrg-fps:1.6] capture [ms:622 avrg-ms:623 fps:1.607717041800643 avrg-fps:1.6051364365971108] capture [ms:616 avrg-ms:619 fps:1.6233766233766234 avrg-fps:1.615508885298869] [/code]

item.title: Java's Robot "createScreenCapture", is there anything better?
item.dc:creator: @Killer-99-pkz Killer-99-pkz
item.description:
@Killer-99-pkz wrote:

Unhandled:

I somehow doubt windows uses an array to store the screen contents.

Image (Array (“list”) of RGB’s to be send to the screen) on RAM or GFX card memory (buffer…) -> screen

Read full topic

item.title: Java's Robot "createScreenCapture", is there anything better?
item.dc:creator: @Killer-99-pkz Killer-99-pkz
item.description:
@Killer-99-pkz wrote:

You know what, come to think of it the packets dont really have to be in direct order, because it has to get updated at some time. but the problem with that is if you move your mouse one place and click, that will click then move if it’s ordered rong. iv’e considered a udp layer but networking isnt my #1 problem at the moment, screen capturing is.[br][br][size=1]Posted on: September 28, 2009, 06:38:46 am[/size][hr]if the windows desktop uses a 1 dimensional array for desktop buffering (in cpp) which im sure it does if it’s this fast… i could easily do this.

Read full topic

item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

Hello, my name is super_. I attempt to prove someone wrong with no information to back me up, except my word. If I would’ve cared enough to make a simple search on google, I would’ve seen that abraham2119 was right.

http://www.29west.com/docs/THPM/udp-buffer-sizing.html
http://lists.netfilter.org/pipermail/netfilter-devel/2002-November/009899.html

item.title: Java's Robot "createScreenCapture", is there anything better?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“abraham2119, post:36, topic:303290”][quote author=abraham2119 link=topic=399617.msg2968189#msg2968189 date=1253752475]
from what ive read, udp only fails to send a packet because of huge buffers being allocated. its not that the packets dont arrive, its mostly that the kernel disposes them before it arrives to your app
[/quote]am i wrong? :S[/quote]

I’ve never heard of that, and it would depend on the individual implementation of the protocol. But that is not the only way they wouldn’t arrive, it could be many things and it really doesn’t matter to the application programmer, you just can’t count on them arriving in your application.

Read full topic

item.source: Java's Robot "createScreenCapture", is there anything better?

item.title: Java's Robot "createScreenCapture", is there anything better?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

DAMN IT PEOPLE!!! WHEN YOU USE UDP YOU DON’T “RISK LOSING A PACKET”!!!

When programming, engineering, or anything similar, you should never take risks. An engineer doesn’t “risk a bridge collapse” when using a certain type of material, he takes precautions, reinforces it as needed, and does whatever he can do to ensure that no matter what the bridge will never collapse.

The same thing applies in programming, and for UDP. You don’t program a login using UDP with the notion that “the packets usually get through” or something stupid like that, because it is not guaranteed and sometimes it will fail. But also, just because you need a guarantee that certain packets will get through you don’t need to use TCP and all the overhead that comes with it. Basically what you will want to do is, in the cases that matter (login for example) you will have to do the type of error checking that is built into TCP, such as making sure you have all the packets that were sent and that they are in the correct order. UDP already makes sure the packets are correct when they are delivered to you (because it implements a checksum, and if it is wrong, it will just not be delivered to your applications) Then in the cases where you don’t want delayed packets (MMORPG location updates, movie/audio frames) don’t bother with the special checking and just work with what gets through.

Understand now? UDP isn’t unreliable or not worth using just because it isn’t TCP, both have their uses and one is only better than the other in certain cases. Think about it like sorting algorithms, for random data quick-sort is the fastest, but for almost-ordered data (where only a handful are out of place) quick-sort is horribly slow while bubble-sort is blindingly fast. You don’t use a screw driver to remove a hex-head bolt. Use what fits the problem.

Read full topic
item.source: Java's Robot "createScreenCapture", is there anything better?

item.title: Java's Robot "createScreenCapture", is there anything better?
item.dc:creator: @Killer-99-pkz Killer-99-pkz
item.description:
@Killer-99-pkz wrote:

[quote=“PeeHPee, post:23, topic:303290”][quote author=Killer-99-pkz link=topic=399617.msg2967404#msg2967404 date=1253681409]
hmm… i wonder what method the print screen button function uses…
[/quote]
YOU HONESTLY THINK PRINT SCREEN USES JAVA???[/quote]
No you mumbling moron, I wanted to know what method in PROBABLY c++ or C#… then i can write a jni library, moron.[br][br][size=1]Posted on: September 25, 2009, 06:29:45 am[/size][hr]You can just pull the desktop window in c++ and work with thatm that’s what most people do. the only reason im writing this in java because i want it to work on linux and windows or whatever else will support it.[br][br][size=1]Posted on: September 25, 2009, 06:31:14 am[/size][hr][quote=“abraham2119, post:29, topic:303290”]as lawl said, use a fast language like c or c++. java is simply not enough

ps i highly recommend it to be p2p and for speed use the udp protocol. from what ive read, udp only fails to send a packet because of huge buffers being allocated. its not that the packets dont arrive, its mostly that the kernel disposes them before it arrives to your app. also, be sure to create a ‘packet-tagging’ system seeing as how udp packets sometimes dont arrive in order (mopar, why dont you tell us more on udp :P)

by the way, on windows, cant you do something like get the desktop handle, then hook WM_GETMESSAGE look out for WM_PAINT events and get the clipped area? i dont know how this would be on linux and such though

the only downside to not using java and using c or c++ is that making the application portable will be annoying[/quote]
Yes I considered udp but since this will be sending mouse movements and clicks, etc… I cant risk loosing the packet.[br][br][size=1]Posted on: September 25, 2009, 06:33:28 am[/size][hr][quote=“Taharok, post:22, topic:303290”][quote author=D e n v e r link=topic=399617.msg2967560#msg2967560 date=1253713080]

hmm… i wonder what method the print screen button function uses…

much faster than what java can do , so you can’t actually compare
[/quote]

[tt]java.awt.peer.RobotPeer.getRGB(java.awt.Rectangle)[/tt] (I think I got that right…) uses a native method to get the pixels. So yes, you can compare them.[/quote]
i haxed it for the getRGBPixels(int x, int y, int width, int height, int[] rgbpixels) >=)

Read full topic

item.title: Java's Robot "createScreenCapture", is there anything better?
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

[quote=“oksuper_, post:32, topic:303290”]I heard BitBlt(GetDC(HWND_DESKTOP), …) is tough?[/quote]using the way i stated, his application could actually block until a the current frame has been repainted, clip it and send it, instead of constantly capturing the current frame shown, comparing it to the old one, etc

it will be much faster

Read full topic

item.title: Java's Robot "createScreenCapture", is there anything better?
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“D e n v e r, post:30, topic:303290”][quote author=D e n v e r link=topic=399617.msg2967765#msg2967765 date=1253733102]

hmm… i wonder what method the print screen button function uses…

YOU HONESTLY THINK PRINT SCREEN USES JAVA???

He didn’t say that, I would hope he knows it’s a native function.

then he asked a pretty broad question.

The question is initially useless :P, why’d he care now its all a matter of milliseconds…
[/quote][/quote]

You must not have ever worked with videos or games before. Every millisecond counts. If a frame is slower by even a few milliseconds, you might end up loosing another frame in the process.

Read full topic

item.title: Java's Robot "createScreenCapture", is there anything better?
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

as lawl said, use a fast language like c or c++. java is simply not enough

ps i highly recommend it to be p2p and for speed use the udp protocol. from what ive read, udp only fails to send a packet because of huge buffers being allocated. its not that the packets dont arrive, its mostly that the kernel disposes them before it arrives to your app. also, be sure to create a ‘packet-tagging’ system seeing as how udp packets sometimes dont arrive in order (mopar, why dont you tell us more on udp :P)

by the way, on windows, cant you do something like get the desktop handle, then hook WM_GETMESSAGE look out for WM_PAINT events and get the clipped area? i dont know how this would be on linux and such though

the only downside to not using java and using c or c++ is that making the application portable will be annoying

Read full topic

item.title: Java's Robot "createScreenCapture", is there anything better?
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

@OP: [tt]createScreenCapture()[/tt] is a bad method to do your test on. If you directly call the peer’s pixel grabber method, you will cut the time it takes to get the screen in half. Since you are sending raw pixels, it is incredibly impractical to go through the extra operations of creating an image just to recall the pixels anyway.

If I recall correctly, I was able to record about 500x500 pixels with the framerate of about 5-10, back when I was naively working on a screen capturer. Java really isn’t the language for desktop recording.

inb4someone complains that Java is as good as any language, etc.

Read full topic
item.source: Java's Robot "createScreenCapture", is there anything better?
